body:
Note that you that get the same  "Cross Origin WebSocket Attempt" exception with current master:

```
{'commit_hash': '2cb5efa',
 'commit_source': 'repository',
 'default_encoding': 'UTF-8',
 'ipython_path': '/home/peter/src/ipython.git/ipython/IPython',
 'ipython_version': '2.1.0-dev',
 'os_name': 'posix',
 'platform': 'Linux-3.11.0-15-generic-i686-with-LinuxMint-16-petra',
 'sys_executable': '/home/peter/src/ipython.git/bin/python',
 'sys_platform': 'linux2',
 'sys_version': '2.7.5+ (default, Feb 27 2014, 19:39:55) \n[GCC 4.8.1]'}
```

The only httpd.conf change needed is to forward different path:

```
    ProxyPass /api/kernels/ ws://127.0.0.1:8888/api/kernels/
    ProxyPassReverse /api/kernels/ ws://127.0.0.1:8888/api/kernels/
```

You still need to spoof the headers.
Pinging @rgbkrk on this one. Does your tornado PR make it easier to have a proper origin check?

You should actually be setting Host, not Origin.

Origin is self-reported by your browser to let the server know where the resource was requested from. If you change the Origin, you'll be circumventing this protection and allowing for the IPython notebook's websockets to be used cross domains (which may not be yours).

I'll get some more details posted about this shortly.

> Does your tornado PR make it easier to have a proper origin check?

What we probably need to do is provide a configuration option for allowed origins.

> You should actually be setting Host, not Origin.

It makes sense but I wasn't sure whether Host isn't used by notebook for other purposes. So I decided to fiddle with Origin.

I only used this on internal network so I didn't really care about cross domain websockets.

I can implement the config option and send a pull request next week if you're interested.
@realcundo How does the configurable origin checking in master work for you, introduced as part of #6061?

@rgbkrk Looks good, I'm happy with the extra parameter, thanks! The only drawback I found (maybe it's intentional!) is that notebook now allows ANY origin by default. The reason is that `allow_origin_pat` is empty by default and calling `re.match()` will match anything so `check_origin()` always returns True. I.e.

``` Python
bool(re.compile(r"").match("evil-host"))
```

is True.
If allow_origin_pat is empty, it should be unused, so only Origin == Host will be allowed. If you can provide a counter-example, that would be a bug.
Aha, I just looked at the code and it is definitely a bug. Fixed by #6105

#6105 fixed it. Default/empty `allow_origin` and `allow_origin_pat` now correctly throw exception.

For completeness, I'm using this `httpd.conf`:

```
<VirtualHost *:8999>
  ProxyPass / ws://127.0.0.1:8888/
  ProxyPassReverse / ws://127.0.0.1:8888/
</VirtualHost>
```

Apache is running on port 8999 and IPython notebook on 8888. Running IPython with `--NotebookApp.allow_origin="http://localhost:8999"` enables websocket forwarding. No workarounds are necessary.
Excellent. Thanks for checking.

Still not able to use the notebook. 
Getting the error again and again : 
"A WebSocket connection could not be established. You will NOT be able to run code. Check your network connection or notebook server configuration."
I am on : 
- iPython 2.1.0
- Apache/2.4.7 (Ubuntu)

Help please. Seems like the realcundo's solution has no effect in my case. Websocket loses connection.

The way I approached the problem originally is that I didn't really care much about apache, it was IPython notebook console log that provided the most useful information -- check for exceptions and or "WARNING | Cross Origin WebSocket Attempt".

Ipython console is not showing any error/warning.  Although when I create a new notebook, the same error popup "WebSocket connection failed". 

my apache conf is something like : 

```
<VirtualHost *:443>
    SSLProxyEngine On
    SSLCertificateFile /home/blackhole/Apps/mycert.pem
    SSLProxyVerify none 
    SSLProxyCheckPeerCN off
    SSLProxyCheckPeerName off

    ProxyPass /kernels/ ws://0.0.0.0:8888/api/kernels/
    ProxyPassReverse /kernels/ ws://0.0.0.0:8888/api/kernels/

    ProxyPass / https://0.0.0.0:8888/
    ProxyPassReverse / https://0.0.0.0:8888/
    Header set Origin "https://127.0.0.1:8888"   
    RequestHeader set Origin "https://127.0.0.1:8888"   

    LogLevel debug
</VirtualHost>

```

If there is nothing in the console apache is not connecting to it. Try a simpler setup - e.g. don't use SSL and use IPython and Apache on the same machine.

Make sure you can connect to IPython Notebook directly (without apache) and check that the prt numbers and URL paths match the ones you set up in apache. Different versions of IPython use different paths (I don't know off the top of my head which one is correct in your case.) The config I posted in the bug is all I had to do to make it work.
@vinaychittora note that the fixes are in IPython 2.x, not in the released 2.1.0. They will be in the next bugfix release.

I'm having the same issue; here is my config

<VirtualHost *:80>
  ProxyPass / ws://127.0.0.1:8888/
  ProxyPassReverse / ws://127.0.0.1:8888/
</VirtualHost>

Apache is running on port 80 and IPython notebook on 8888 (or 443)
Running IPython with --NotebookApp.allow_origin="http://localhost:80"

I can create and access notebooks on 8888 (or 443), and I can access through the proxy, but when I try to create a notebook through the proxy, I get the error message:

"WebSocket connection failed
A WebSocket connection could not be established. You will NOT be able to run code. Check your network connection or notebook server configuration."

Hello,

I'm still not able to use the notebook; getting the same error: 

"A WebSocket connection could not be established. You will NOT be able to run code. Check your network connection or notebook server configuration."

I am using:
- Python 2.7
- iPython 2.2.0
- Apache/2.4 (Ubuntu)
- Tornado 4.0.2

I'm not really sure what #6105 addressed, but I would appreciate any insight or assistance.

Here is my wsdump.py output:

```
wsdump.py ws://localhost:8888/tree -vv
--- request header ---
GET /tree HTTP/1.1
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Host: localhost:8888
Origin: http://localhost:8888
Sec-WebSocket-Key: LjW5oWbjQ+6NbexGU2Qi0A==
Sec-WebSocket-Version: 13

-----------------------
--- response header ---
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Content-Length: 0
Set-Cookie: username-localhost-8888=; expires=Sat, 14 Sep 2013 17:23:47 GMT; Path=/
Server: TornadoServer/4.0.2
Location: /login?next=%2Ftree
Date: Sun, 14 Sep 2014 17:23:47 GMT
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://localhost:80
-----------------------
Handshake status 302
```

Any suggestions would be appreciated!

p.s.: not really sure why the 'Access-Control-Allow...' line above is formatted the way it is.

@snotes The Access Control Allow Origin line is set with what you passed in https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/5525#issuecomment-53520637.

The reason this was fixed in this way was a mitigation for a [vulnerability with cross origin websockets](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1119890#c0) and is why requests are being denied. We need a good workaround that isn't going to open local users up to attacks.

My environment is:
Python 2.7.8 |Anaconda 2.1.0 (64-bit)| (default, Aug 21 2014, 18:22:21) 
[GCC 4.4.7 20120313 (Red Hat 4.4.7-1)] on linux2

Reverse proxy is Apache listening on port 8888 with SSL with this config:

```
<VirtualHost *:8888>
ServerName myreverseproxy.acme.net
SSLEngine on
SSLCertificateFile /etc/pki/httpd/https.crt
SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/pki/httpd/https.key

ProxyPass /ipython http://notebook-server.acme.net:8008/ipython
ProxyPassReverse /ipython http://notebook-server.acme.net:8008/ipython

ProxyPreserveHost Off
</VirtualHost>
```

notebook server config is:

```
c.NotebookApp.base_url = '/ipython/'
c.NotebookApp.base_kernel_url = '/ipython/'
c.NotebookApp.port = 8008
c.NotebookApp.trust_xheaders = True
c.NotebookApp.webapp_settings = {'static_url_prefix': '/ipython/static/'}
c.NotebookApp.allow_origin = '*'
c.NotebookApp.notebook_dir = u'/usr/local/anaconda/usernotebooks'
c.NotebookApp.ip = '*'
c.NotebookApp.open_browser = False
```

Is there a workaround for at least testing the functionality if I am not too concerned about attacks against local users? Thanks.
[This StackOverflow post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23890386/how-to-run-ipython-behind-an-apache-proxy) seems to help regarding how to set your Apache config and to install `proxy_wstunnel`.

@rgbkrk Thanks for the quick response. That was the first link I hit when I started install/config. As you see, the response notes "but having some iPython web socket errors that need to be resolved once I have logged in and try to execute a new notepad (help here is appreciated)."

And that is exactly where I am stuck too.

Ok, so Apache might not be the issue here. After I got the basic SSL+Proxy going, I added basic auth and the whole thing broke again under nginx. I went back and forth between auth and no-auth a few times to confirm and yep, adding auth breaks websockets. Don't know why.

As stop gap, I excluded the "ipython" location from basic auth (leaving other apps to use nginx auth) and set auth on the notebook server.
